pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
The seat collision model also got lowered a few cm I think? It still seems to be fairly high for Atlas to properly use the pedals though.

Not related to this pull-request but for the 2.3 roadmap, here's our version of the polaris ranger that we've been using so far which has visually moving steering wheel and wheels, feel free to integrate it with the updated version (so I don't have to do it on our end ;) ): www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/polaris_ranger_ev_drivable.tar.gz

Btw will the pedals stay prismatic joints or are you planning on changing them to use revolute joints (i.e. an arm that is being pushed, like it is with a real pedal)?
content.html:
The seat collision model also got lowered a few cm I think? It still seems to be fairly high for Atlas to properly use the pedals though.

Not related to this pull-request but for the 2.3 roadmap, here's our version of the polaris ranger that we've been using so far which has visually moving steering wheel and wheels, feel free to integrate it with the updated version (so I don't have to do it on our end ;) ): www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/polaris_ranger_ev_drivable.tar.gz

Btw will the pedals stay prismatic joints or are you planning on changing them to use revolute joints (i.e. an arm that is being pushed, like it is with a real pedal)?

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
Right, I forgot to mention that I lowered the seat a bit. I've been able to reach the pedals with this setup. I'll work on making a video.

I'll confer with @nkoenig on integrating your meshes, as separate files, since he's been working on a solution for selecting specific nodes from a dae file.

Until we have any data on the polaris pedal parameters, I'm not planning to change them. Qualitatively, they seem to be working as prismatic joints.
content.html:
Right, I forgot to mention that I lowered the seat a bit. I've been able to reach the pedals with this setup. I'll work on making a video.

I'll confer with @nkoenig on integrating your meshes, as separate files, since he's been working on a solution for selecting specific nodes from a dae file.

Until we have any data on the polaris pedal parameters, I'm not planning to change them. Qualitatively, they seem to be working as prismatic joints.

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
" I've been able to reach the pedals with this setup."

Atlas certainly is able to reach the pedals in the new position, but the problem I see is that there's still ~5cm space between feet and vehicle floor, so you wouldn't be able to support your foot while actuating the pedals or balance your body while taking turns using the legs like a real person would. It might also increase difficulty of ingress and egress as the robot has to sit down on a platform that is higher than it is able to reach by without doing some complex stretching (at least that's what it looks like to me at the moment).

When you look at normal persons sitting in a Polaris Ranger EV they're always able to reach the ground with their feet very comfortably (unless they're far below average height I guess, but Atlas is supposed to have the measurements of a 50th percentile human): http://i.imgur.com/AbMfpZ1.png


Btw could you add 

        if (this->vehicleRobotJoint)
          this->RemoveJoint(this->vehicleRobotJoint);

to the ``nominal`` mode in order to be able to unpin the robot inside the vehicle? Or are you planning on pinning Atlas to the seat once it finished sitting down?

Edit:
I just tried having atlas sit inside the vehicle unpinned which shows an increased need for proper leg-support ... I don't know what happened but after a few seconds of not watching simulation it looked like this: http://i.imgur.com/GPBhqJx.jpg

Might make a nice vehicle egress behaviour  or some mission impossible stunts while driving though. It seems like the robot drifts way too much while sitting inside the vehicle (at least when using default physics parameters). It takes about 20 seconds to drift from initial pose (0,0,0) all the way to the front of the seat until it collides with the steering wheel.
content.html:
" I've been able to reach the pedals with this setup."

Atlas certainly is able to reach the pedals in the new position, but the problem I see is that there's still ~5cm space between feet and vehicle floor, so you wouldn't be able to support your foot while actuating the pedals or balance your body while taking turns using the legs like a real person would. It might also increase difficulty of ingress and egress as the robot has to sit down on a platform that is higher than it is able to reach by without doing some complex stretching (at least that's what it looks like to me at the moment).

When you look at normal persons sitting in a Polaris Ranger EV they're always able to reach the ground with their feet very comfortably (unless they're far below average height I guess, but Atlas is supposed to have the measurements of a 50th percentile human): http://i.imgur.com/AbMfpZ1.png

Btw could you add 

    if (this->vehicleRobotJoint)
      this->RemoveJoint(this->vehicleRobotJoint);

to the nominal mode in order to be able to unpin the robot inside the vehicle? Or are you planning on pinning Atlas to the seat once it finished sitting down?

Edit: I just tried having atlas sit inside the vehicle unpinned which shows an increased need for proper leg-support ... I don't know what happened but after a few seconds of not watching simulation it looked like this: http://i.imgur.com/GPBhqJx.jpg

Might make a nice vehicle egress behaviour or some mission impossible stunts while driving though. It seems like the robot drifts way too much while sitting inside the vehicle (at least when using default physics parameters). It takes about 20 seconds to drift from initial pose (0,0,0) all the way to the front of the seat until it collides with the steering wheel.

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
The model is currently missing a lot of the entrance collision detail, i.e. the floor is not as wide as in the visual model and all the slopy stuff on the side of the entrance and the center of the vehicle is missing:

* http://i.imgur.com/MFnzNSY.jpg
* http://i.imgur.com/zKtkcuk.png
* http://i.imgur.com/uYiiXPf.jpg

I'm not really shouting for a change (as it gives more room to move with the slopy stuff missing), I just mainly want to know whether collision models for these sections will still be added or whether the model will stay the way it is in these areas.
content.html:
The model is currently missing a lot of the entrance collision detail, i.e. the floor is not as wide as in the visual model and all the slopy stuff on the side of the entrance and the center of the vehicle is missing:

  • http://i.imgur.com/MFnzNSY.jpg
  • http://i.imgur.com/zKtkcuk.png
  • http://i.imgur.com/uYiiXPf.jpg

I'm not really shouting for a change (as it gives more room to move with the slopy stuff missing), I just mainly want to know whether collision models for these sections will still be added or whether the model will stay the way it is in these areas.

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw: We are open to suggestions but are interested in minimizing the number of changes to the model as we get closer to the competition. I'm not planning to implement the "slopy stuff", would it help to have a wider floor?
content.html: We are open to suggestions but are interested in minimizing the number of changes to the model as we get closer to the competition. I'm not planning to implement the "slopy stuff", would it help to have a wider floor?

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
The entrance + floor should be good the way it is now. I don't think there's any significant difference in having a wider or shorter floor - the short version might actually be easier.

Will the robot be able to reach the floor while seated (see other comment)? Not being able to do so makes it significantly more difficult as it requires behaviours closer to a small child than an (average sized) adult.
content.html:
The entrance + floor should be good the way it is now. I don't think there's any significant difference in having a wider or shorter floor - the short version might actually be easier.

Will the robot be able to reach the floor while seated (see other comment)? Not being able to do so makes it significantly more difficult as it requires behaviours closer to a small child than an (average sized) adult.

content.raw: I haven't had a chance to make that video yet, but when I did it I had to angle the foot all the way down so the "toes" touch the floor. There may be more reach if the thighs are angled down, but this might require a "butt".
content.html: I haven't had a chance to make that video yet, but when I did it I had to angle the foot all the way down so the "toes" touch the floor. There may be more reach if the thighs are angled down, but this might require a "butt".

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
Not sure whether those issues are intended for this pull-request given that it's experimental, or whether the features are left out, but:

* button interface is missing - esp. F/N/R switch (I'd also like a mode switch to secretly switch to the 40kph mode while no one is looking! ;) )
* there's two hand brakes - which position will be the one used for VRC?
* no keyswitch - will we need to use it or will this only be a requirement for DRC?
* completely black steering wheel - it works better than I expected it would but a proper non-constant-black texture would be preferred. Please use the previous visual steering wheel (or its texture) if possible.
content.html:
Not sure whether those issues are intended for this pull-request given that it's experimental, or whether the features are left out, but:

  • button interface is missing - esp. F/N/R switch (I'd also like a mode switch to secretly switch to the 40kph mode while no one is looking! ;) )
  • there's two hand brakes - which position will be the one used for VRC?
  • no keyswitch - will we need to use it or will this only be a requirement for DRC?
  • completely black steering wheel - it works better than I expected it would but a proper non-constant-black texture would be preferred. Please use the previous visual steering wheel (or its texture) if possible.

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
We're working on the steering texture. @nkoenig and I are discussing whether to use the mesh you've provided or to attach collada nodes from a larger mesh as visuals.

The handbrake that has the wood texture is the one that actually works, the other is just part of the visual mesh, and is more involved to remove.

Can you file issues for the button interface and key switch in the drcsim issue tracker?
content.html:
We're working on the steering texture. @nkoenig and I are discussing whether to use the mesh you've provided or to attach collada nodes from a larger mesh as visuals.

The handbrake that has the wood texture is the one that actually works, the other is just part of the visual mesh, and is more involved to remove.

Can you file issues for the button interface and key switch in the drcsim issue tracker?

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
I've updated this model to use submeshes. There is a soon-to-be released pull request that will enable this feature. The working branch is called `submesh_geometry`.

Here is how this will be released:

1) We merge in the SDF 1.4 pull request.

2) I merge in the submesh changes.

3) We create a polaris SDF file with the changes in this pull request for SDF 1.4. The old polaris model will remain unchanged.

So, anyone working off of default can use the new polaris, and other users will not be effected.
content.html:
I've updated this model to use submeshes. There is a soon-to-be released pull request that will enable this feature. The working branch is called submesh_geometry.

Here is how this will be released:

1) We merge in the SDF 1.4 pull request.

2) I merge in the submesh changes.

3) We create a polaris SDF file with the changes in this pull request for SDF 1.4. The old polaris model will remain unchanged.

So, anyone working off of default can use the new polaris, and other users will not be effected.

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
Apply the following patch to drcsim to test with "mud" on the seat. This will generate damping forces to stabilize seat contact.
~~~
diff -r f6ecf4dadc80 gazebo_models/environments/drc_vehicle/model.sdf
--- a/gazebo_models/environments/drc_vehicle/model.sdf	Thu Apr 25 12:16:30 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo_models/environments/drc_vehicle/model.sdf	Thu Apr 25 18:40:14 2013 -0700
@@ -23,5 +23,11 @@
       <max_speed>10</max_speed>
       <aero_load>0.1</aero_load>
     </plugin>
+    <plugin name="seat_mud" filename="libMudPlugin.so">
+      <contact_sensor_name>polaris_ranger_ev/chassis/seat_contact</contact_sensor_name>
+      <stiffness>0.0</stiffness>
+      <damping>100.0</damping>
+      <link_name>atlas::pelvis</link_name>
+    </plugin>
   </model>
 </sdf>
~~~
content.html:
Apply the following patch to drcsim to test with "mud" on the seat. This will generate damping forces to stabilize seat contact.

diff -r f6ecf4dadc80 gazebo_models/environments/drc_vehicle/model.sdf
--- a/gazebo_models/environments/drc_vehicle/model.sdf  Thu Apr 25 12:16:30 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo_models/environments/drc_vehicle/model.sdf  Thu Apr 25 18:40:14 2013 -0700
@@ -23,5 +23,11 @@
       <max_speed>10</max_speed>
       <aero_load>0.1</aero_load>
     </plugin>
+    <plugin name="seat_mud" filename="libMudPlugin.so">
+      <contact_sensor_name>polaris_ranger_ev/chassis/seat_contact</contact_sensor_name>
+      <stiffness>0.0</stiffness>
+      <damping>100.0</damping>
+      <link_name>atlas::pelvis</link_name>
+    </plugin>
   </model>
 </sdf>

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw: How will the prismatic joint that's planned to be added according to the drc forum work alongside the mud? Will the prismatic joint constrain motion to 1DOF and mud takes care of damping? Or is the prismatic joint thing outdated already?
content.html: How will the prismatic joint that's planned to be added according to the drc forum work alongside the mud? Will the prismatic joint constrain motion to 1DOF and mud takes care of damping? Or is the prismatic joint thing outdated already?

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw: The prismatic joint may not be needed if the new pelvis meshes and "mud" can make the seat contact sufficiently stable.
content.html: The prismatic joint may not be needed if the new pelvis meshes and "mud" can make the seat contact sufficiently stable.

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
Some questions:
And how you propose to define sufficiently stable? by the rate the robot slides around when everything is otherwise stationary? The mean time until the robot slides off the seat? What solver parameters will you be using to test? 

Our approach is to slide across when seated from the passanger seat. how will the 'mud' effect lateral motion? What time frame do you propose to give the teams to test this approach and to give feedback?

And when will the vehicle be complete? (Some of our team say that its difficult to develop when the vehicle is changing so much)
content.html:
Some questions: And how you propose to define sufficiently stable? by the rate the robot slides around when everything is otherwise stationary? The mean time until the robot slides off the seat? What solver parameters will you be using to test?

Our approach is to slide across when seated from the passanger seat. how will the 'mud' effect lateral motion? What time frame do you propose to give the teams to test this approach and to give feedback?

And when will the vehicle be complete? (Some of our team say that its difficult to develop when the vehicle is changing so much)

pullrequest.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

content.raw:
In my testing, I look at how much the robot slides while the vehicle is stationary (and it appears to be much improved with the new atlas meshes) and also when undergoing some acceleration. To test this, I have the vehicle still and change gravity to give longitudinal or lateral components. If the robot has feet on the floor, it can tolerate accelerations. However, it may require some stabilization of the torso when turning sharply.

We have an internal deadline to finish the vehicle by today and a week or two before feature freeze to respond to feedback from teams.

The "mud" applies viscous forces but isn't sticky, so I imagine one could still slide across the seat, though it may slow that process somewhat.
content.html:
In my testing, I look at how much the robot slides while the vehicle is stationary (and it appears to be much improved with the new atlas meshes) and also when undergoing some acceleration. To test this, I have the vehicle still and change gravity to give longitudinal or lateral components. If the robot has feet on the floor, it can tolerate accelerations. However, it may require some stabilization of the torso when turning sharply.

We have an internal deadline to finish the vehicle by today and a week or two before feature freeze to respond to feedback from teams.

The "mud" applies viscous forces but isn't sticky, so I imagine one could still slide across the seat, though it may slow that process somewhat.
